method.name: multivalue_config
method.description: This procedure is used to create and modify multivalue operations. Multivalue is a very powerful represetation in NGPF. This is useful to generate various patterns like increment, decrement, custom pattern from file, repeatable random, overlay and etc. This command returns a handle for the configured multivalue. This handle can be used in interface and protocol configuration command to set patterns/multivalue against various fields.

description.text: The mode parameter is only needed when specifying values for custom_handle or increment_handle. When a custom_handle is specified the only valid mode values are - create - modify When a increment_handle is specified all choices are valid.

choice.choiceText: creates a new CustomIncrement with the specified values
updates the root CustomIncrement with the specified values

description.text: The handle of a multivalue that was generated by a previous multivalue_config command.
The handle of a custom pattern that was generated by a previous multivalue_config command.
The handle of a custom increment that was generated by a previous multivalue_config command.
The pattern that we want the multivalue to have.

restriction.value: none single_value counter custom repeatable_random random repeatable_random_range custom_distributed distributed string alternate value_list subset

description.text: The value that will be used when the pattern is single_value. This argument is valid only if the configured pattern is single_value.
The start value that will be used when the pattern is a counter. This argument is valid only if the configured pattern is counter.
The step value that will be used when the pattern is a counter. This argument is valid only if the configured pattern is counter.
The type of counter pattern that we want to configure. This argument is valid only if the configured pattern is counter.

The step of the configured nest(s) for the current multivalue. If multiple nests are configured the value of this argument must be a comma separated list of step values which correspond to the specified nest owners.
The owner of the configured nest(s) for the current multivalue. If multiple nests are configured the value of this argument must be a comma separated list of owner handles.

This argument can be used to selectively enable/disable the nests configured in a multivalue. If multiple nests are configured the value of this argument must be a comma separated list of step values which correspond to the specified nest owners.
This flag can be used to disable all nests in a multivalue.
The value of an overlay. This argument can be a comma separated list of values if we want to configure multiple overlays with a single command.

The step used by an overlay. This argument should only be used if you want to create overlay patterns. This argument can be a comma separated list of values if we want to configure multiple overlays with a single command.
The index at which the overlay will be created. This argument can be a comma separated list of values if we want to configure multiple overlays with a single command.

The index step controls the inteval at which successive overlays will be created. This argument should only be used if you want to create overlay patterns. This argument can be a comma separated list of values if we want to configure multiple overlays with a single command.

The number of overlays which will be generated by the corresponding overlay pattern. This argument should only be used if you want to create overlay patterns. This argument can be a comma separated list of values if we want to configure multiple overlays with a single command.
This flag can be used to remove all overlays from a multivalue.
The start value for the custom pattern. This argument is valid only if the configured pattern is custom.
The step value for the custom pattern. This argument is valid only if the configured pattern is custom.
The value of the custom increment being configured by the current command. This argument is valid only if the configured pattern is custom.
The count of the custom increment being configured by the current command. This argument is valid only if the configured pattern is custom.
The seed that will be used by the repeatable random pattern configured by the current command. This argument is valid only if the configured pattern is repeatable_random.
The number of random values that will be generated by the repeatable random pattern configured by the current command. This argument is valid only if the configured pattern is repeatable_random.
A template that can be used to configure a static part of the values that will be generated. This argument is valid only if the configured pattern is repeatable_random.
A mask that can be used to select which parts of the fixed value will not be changed when a new value is generated. This argument is valid only if the configured pattern is repeatable_random.
This is the minimum value of the range generated by the repeatable random range This argument is valid only if the configured pattern is repeatable_random_range.
This is the maximum value of the range generated by the repeatable random range This argument is valid only if the configured pattern is repeatable_random_range.
This is the minimum difference between generated value by the repeatable random range This argument is valid only if the configured pattern is repeatable_random_range.
The seed that will be used by the repeatable random range pattern configured by the current command. This argument is valid only if the configured pattern is repeatable_random_range.
The values that will be used by the custom distributed multivalue configured by this command. This argument is valid only if the configured pattern is custom_distributed.
The distribution percentages that will be used. This argument is valid only if the configured pattern is custom_distributed.
The distribution weights that will be used. This argument is valid only if the configured pattern is custom_distributed.
The algorithm that will be used to distribute the values specified in custom_distribution_values.

choice.choiceText: The values specified by custom_distribution_values will be distributed evenly.
The values specified by custom_distribution_values will be distributed geometrically.
The values specified by custom_distribution_values will be distributed according to the percentages specified in custom_distribution_percentages.
The values specified by custom_distribution_values will be distributed accorgind to the weights specified in custom_distribution_percentages.

description.text: The mode in which the distribution algorithm specified by custom_distribution_algorithm will be applied.

choice.choiceText: The values specified in custom_distribution_values will be distributed across all the configured devices according to the distribution algorithm specified by custom_distribution_algorithm.

The values specified in custom_distribution_values will be distributed across each set of devices configured for a parent device according to the distribution algorithm specified by custom_distribution_algorithm.

The values specified in custom_distribution_values will be distributed across each set of devices configured on a port according to the distribution algorithm specified by custom_distribution_algorithm.

description.text: The value that will be distributed among the individual items configured with the current multivalue. This argument is valid only if the configured pattern is distributed.
The string pattern that will be used by the multivalue configured by the current command. This argument is valid only if the configured pattern is string.
The start value for the alternate pattern.
A list of values that will be used to populate the corresponding attribute. If not enough values are supplied, the existing values will be reused as many times as necessary.

The full path of a local file that will be used to import the list of values for the value_list pattern. The file should be in either CSV, CISCO or Juniper format. This argument's value will be used only if th values_list argument was not manually specified.

The type of file that will be used to import the list of values for the value_list pattern. This argument is used only when values_file is specified and used as well and it has a default value of csv.

choice.choiceText: Indicates that the file specified by values_file has a CISCO format.
Indicates that the file specified by values_file has a CSV format.
Indicates that the file specified by values_file has a JUNIPER format.
Indicates that the file specified by values_file has an unsupported format.

description.text: The 0-based index of the column that will be used to import the values. This argument is used only when values_file is specified and used as well and it has a default value of 0.
The handle of the protocol stack that will be used as a source of values for the corresponding attribute.

The name of the attribute that will be used as a source of values. The value of this argument will be ignored if no value was specified for subset_source. This argument can be omitted if the destination protocol stack is of the same type as the source protocol stack. In this case the name of the destination attribute will be used as the name of the source attribute.
The type of round robin distribution tat will be used to populate the values of the target attribute using the source values.

returnValue.value: A list containing the multivalue protocol stack handles that were added by the command (if any).
A list containing the custom protocol stack handles that were added by the command (if any).
A list containing the increment protocol stack handles that were added by the command (if any).

code_examples.example:
# Command :- ixiangpf.multivalue_config # This example will configure a multivalue filed of type IP with direction increment
status = ixiangpf.multivalue_config( pattern = "counter", counter_start = "100.1.0.1", counter_step = "0.0.1.0", counter_direction = "increment", nest_step = "0.1.0.0", nest_owner = "<topology_handle>", nest_enabled = "1", ) # The command above will generate output as shown below: # {'status' : '1', 'multivalue_handle' : 'multivalueHandle'} # This example will configure a multivalue filed of type IPv6 with direction decrement
status = ixiangpf.multivalue_config( pattern = "counter", counter_start = "2000::f", counter_step = "::0.0.0.1", counter_direction = "decrement", nest_step = "::0.0.0.1", nest_owner = "<topology_handle>", nest_enabled = "0", ) # The command above will generate output as shown below: # {'status' : '1'} {'multivalue_handle' : 'multivalueHandle'} # This example will configure a multivalue field with some filed being overlay.
status = ixiangpf.multivalue_config( pattern = "counter", counter_start = "100.1.0.1", counter_step = "0.0.1.0", counter_direction = "increment", nest_step = "0.1.0.0", nest_owner = "<topology_handle>", nest_enabled = "1", overlay_value = "100.1.22.1,100.1.23.1", overlay_value_step = "100.1.22.1,100.1.23.1", overlay_index = "5,6", overlay_index_step = "0,0", overlay_count = "1,1", ) # The command above will generate output as shown below: # {'status' : '1'} {'multivalue_handle' : 'multivalueHandle'}

# Command :- ixiangpf::multivalue_config # This example will configure a multivalue filed of type IP with direction increment my $multivalue_status = ixiangpf::multivalue_config ({ pattern => "counter", counter_start => "100.1.0.1", counter_step => "0.0.1.0", counter_direction => "increment", nest_step => "0.1.0.0", nest_owner => "<topology_handle>", nest_enabled => "1", }); # The command above will generate output as shown below: # {status 1} {multivalue_handle multivalueHandle} # This example will configure a multivalue filed of type IPv6 with direction decrement my $multivalue_status = ixiangpf::multivalue_config ({ pattern => "counter", counter_start => "2000::f", counter_step => "::0.0.0.1", counter_direction => "decrement", nest_step => "::0.0.0.1", nest_owner => "<topology_handle>", nest_enabled => "0", }); # The command above will generate output as shown below: # {status 1} {multivalue_handle multivalueHandle} # This example will configure a multivalue field with some filed being overlay. my $multivalue_status = ixiangpf::multivalue_config ({ pattern => "counter", counter_start => "100.1.0.1", counter_step => "0.0.1.0", counter_direction => "increment", nest_step => "0.1.0.0", nest_owner => "<topology_handle>", nest_enabled => "1", overlay_value => "100.1.22.1,100.1.23.1", overlay_value_step => "100.1.22.1,100.1.23.1", overlay_index => "5,6", overlay_index_step => "0,0", overlay_count => "1,1", }); # The command above will generate output as shown below: # {status 1} {multivalue_handle multivalueHandle}

# Command :- Multivalue Config # This example will configure a multivalue filed of type IP with direction increment
${result} = Multivalue Config pattern=counter counter_start=100.1.0.1 counter_step=0.0.1.0 counter_direction=increment ... nest_step=0.1.0.0 nest_owner=<topology_handle> nest_enabled=1 ${status} = Get From Dictionary ${result} status Run Keyword If '${status}' != '1' FAIL "Error: Status is not SUCCESS" ELSE Log "Status is SUCCESS" ${multivalue_status} = Get From Dictionary ${result} multivalue_status
# The command above will generate output as shown below: # {'status' : '1', 'multivalue_handle' : 'multivalueHandle'} # This example will configure a multivalue filed of type IPv6 with direction decrement
${result} = Multivalue Config pattern=counter counter_start=2000::f counter_step=::0.0.0.1 counter_direction=decrement nest_step=::0.0.0.1 nest_owner=<topology_handle> nest_enabled=0 ${status} = Get From Dictionary ${result} status Run Keyword If '${status}' != '1' FAIL "Error: Status is not SUCCESS" ELSE Log "Status is SUCCESS" ${multivalue_status} = Get From Dictionary ${result} multivalue_status
# The command above will generate output as shown below: # {'status' : '1'} {'multivalue_handle' : 'multivalueHandle'} # This example will configure a multivalue field with some filed being overlay.
${result} = Multivalue Config pattern=counter counter_start=100.1.0.1 counter_step=0.0.1.0 counter_direction=increment ... nest_step=0.1.0.0 nest_owner=<topology_handle> nest_enabled=1 overlay_value=100.1.22.1,100.1.23.1 overlay_value_step=100.1.22.1,100.1.23.1 overlay_index=5,6 overlay_index_step=0,0 overlay_count=1,1 ${status} = Get From Dictionary ${result} status Run Keyword If '${status}' != '1' FAIL "Error: Status is not SUCCESS" ELSE Log "Status is SUCCESS" ${multivalue_status} = Get From Dictionary ${result} multivalue_status
# The command above will generate output as shown below: # {'status' : '1'} {'multivalue_handle' : 'multivalueHandle'}
